channel.title: Security engineering talks on Security engineering by vixentael
channel.description: Recent content in Security engineering talks on Security engineering by vixentael

item.title: Use cryptography; don’t learn it
item.description: We’ll talk about “boring crypto”: why developers shouldn’t spend time learning all the details of crypto-algorithms (or invent new ones).

item.title: Maintaining cryptographic library for 12 languages
item.description: Maintaining cross-platform cryptographic library is a journey full of unexpected bugs, language-specific hacks, difficult decisions and endless struggle to make developer-facing APIs easy-to-use and hard-to-misuse.

item.title: 10 lines of encryption, 1500 lines of key management
item.description: The real case about Bear note taking the app that decided to implement convenient note encryption and note locking for their existing user base.

item.title: Defense in depth: trench warfare principles for building secure distributed applications
item.description: It comes to no surprise that any micro-services, any security controls you use to build applications – will eventually be broken (or fail).

item.title: Security, privacy and cryptography at WWDC19
item.description: Apple made many announcements on WWDC 2019 about cryptography, cybersecurity and privacy.

item.title: Protecting sensitive data in modern multi-component systems
item.description: Modern apps are multi-components, and most data leaks are caused by poor architectural decisions.

item.title: Encryption without magic, risk management without pain
item.description: In-depth technical inquiry about application-level encryption. How crypto helps to narrow down significant risks to controlled attack surfaces, enables managing the risk efficiently and elegantly, how tools and algorithms sit in a broader context of managing infrastructure-wide risks associated with handling sensitive data.

item.title: X Things you need to know before implementing cryptography
item.description: Before we get deep into protocols vulnerabilities: things you should remember designing your app flow from a security point of view.

item.title: Making security usable: product engineer perspective
item.description: This is a story of going through typical security challenges: how to build products that reliably deliver security guarantees, avoid typical pitfalls, and are usable in a predictable fashion by real users.

item.title: Zero knowledge architectures for mobile apps
item.description: With intensifying threat access, snooping governments and insecure-internet-of-everything, the importance of zero-knowledge application architectures and end-to-end trust, for things more complicated than simple messaging, becomes more and more obvious for the app developers.
